description:
Telopea speciosissima, commonly known as the New South Wales Waratah, is a species of flowering plant native to the Sydney region of eastern Australia. It belongs to the family Proteaceae and is renowned for its striking, large, red or pink flowers.

The Waratah is an evergreen shrub or small tree, typically growing to a height of 2-6 meters. The leaves are simple, oblong-lanceolate in shape, and measure approximately 10-25 cm in length. The inflorescence is a large, terminal cluster of up to 40 individual flowers, each measuring 10-15 cm in diameter.

The Waratah is adapted to the fire-prone heathland and woodland ecosystems of its native habitat. Its seeds require heat or smoke stimulation to germinate, and the plant can resprout from its lignotuber (a woody, underground stem) after bushfires. The species is pollinated by birds, particularly honeyeaters, which are attracted to the abundant nectar produced by the flowers.

Telopea speciosissima is a highly sought-after ornamental plant, both in its native range and in cultivation around the world. It is also culturally significant to the Indigenous Australians of the region and has been used for traditional medicinal and ceremonial purposes.
